Title: 1 - Foundations
Description: Foundations for a working SAP landscape in Azure.

Title: MaxDB
Description:
Azure storage best practices for SAP MaxDB follow the general recommendations mentioned in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_general#65fa79d6-a85f-47ee-890b-22e794f51a64

For a detailed guide about SAP MaxDB, liveCache, and Content Server deployment on Azure VMs: 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_maxdb#specifics-for-sap-livecache-deployments-on-windows

Title: Non-RDBMS storage considerations
Description:
Premium storage - including Ultra Disk and Azure NetApp Files - are recommended storage devices for all SAP systems.

Some systems, particularly non-production and not under high load, could be used with lesser storage solutions. 
Following table contains a decision matrix when Standard storage could be used and which premium storage type to utilize - link to documentation.

Title: Azure NetApp Files for SAP RDBMS storage
Description:
Azure NeApp Files can be used for storing HANA and Oracle RDBMS. 
NFS 4.1 is a requirement at least for /log and /data.
SAP HANA Azure virtual machine ANF configuration - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs 

For low latency requirements it is essential to follow the storage sizing rules and either use Premium or Ultra service level. SAP HANA Azure virtual machine ANF configuration - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs The provided sizing information are minimum requirements and might differ to real life implementation and IOPS/throughput needs of concrete customer situations.
Oracle RDBMS starting w. version 19c
Deploy SAP AnyDB (Oracle 19c) with Azure NetApp Files - Microsoft Tech Community
2015553 - SAP on Microsoft Azure: Support prerequisites - SAP ONE Support Launchpad

So far no other SAP NetWeaver DBMS supported with Azure NetApp Files, please recheck SAP support note 2015553 (link above).

Title: NFS solutions for SAP in Azure
Tags: Azure NetApp Files; General; High Availability
Description:
SAP NetWeaver and SAP HANA shared directories in a high availability environment do have a need for high available NFS solution to store and allow access to SAP shared directories.
Part of high-availability for SAP NetWeaver NFS is a separate NFS cluster in order to provide access to shared directories to clustered SAP systems. 

SLES:  High availability for NFS on Azure VMs on SLES - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs  

RedHat: GlusterFS on Azure VMs on RHEL for SAP NetWeaver - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

Another NFS solution providing access to SAP shared directories for clustered systems is using Azure NetApp Files Azure VMs high availability for SAP NW on SLES with Azure NetApp Files - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

A second NFS solution for SAP shared directories is NFS 4.1 on Azure files which is currently in preview Deploy SAP ASCS/ERS with Azure Files NFS v4.1 shares - Microsoft Tech Community

NFS shares based on NFS v3 or NFS 4.x could also be used for HANA/DB file backup SAP HANA Azure Backup on file level - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs, please keep in mind that this solution has to be deployed and managed on your own.

Title: Certified VMs for SAP on Azure
Description:
Starting point: SAP certified Azure SKU documentation Microsoft Azure certifications for SAP - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

SAP HANA Certified and Supported SAP HANA® Hardware Directory, for production workloads it is mandatory to use one of the SKU listed there. You must click on the entry to reveal other details and possible restrictions imposed.
For HANA non-prod it is recommended to use SKU listed in SAP note 1928533 - SAP Applications on Azure: Supported Products and Azure VM types - SAP ONE Support Launchpad. This SAP note is documenting supported SKU for SAP NetWeaver, also outlining which SAP products/kernel versions/os versions/db versions are being supported.

Title: Hub Spoke Architecture
Description:
Please find recommended networking -Hub and Spoke- architecture here SAP on Azure Architecture Guide - Azure Architecture Center | Microsoft Docs
HUB and Spoke with peered vnets are generally recommended, where Hub acts as connectivity/security/management entry point vnet, while Spoke vnet isolates workloads like SAP. Hub-spoke network topology in Azure - Azure Reference Architectures | Microsoft Docs Vnet peering allows seamless connection, vnet communication is using Azure backbone. Azure Virtual Network peering | Microsoft Docs Inbound/outbound data transfer between peered vnets is charged Virtual Network Pricing | Microsoft Azure

Title: Linux Pacemaker Cluster
Description:
Clustering on Linux systems can cover alllayers of the SAP system, each would need to be own cluster unless there is documentation available which covers multiple components in one cluster. 
  • NFS layer to provide /sapmnt, /usr/sap/trans and /usr/sap/<SID>/<instances> for (A)SCS/ERS clusters. This could be VM based of NFS as service (see #319 ).  Documentation link.
  • (A)SCS and ERS layer
  • Database layer - depending on database type chosen different implantation options.. Documentation links: SAP HANA, Other databases within section
There is no cluster needed for SAP application servers or WebDispatchers. 
Application servers, if multiple, should be deployed in Availability Set or Availability Zone (see task on AvSet/AvZone in this guide) but without any failover of individual instances - documentation link.
WebDispatchers, if not integrated with ASCS but on own discrete VMs, should be accessible highly available behind a layer 7 reverse proxy/load balancer such as Azure Application Gateway and thus do not require any additional clustering either.

Linux clustering decision on fencing
RedHat Linux only supports use of Azure API Fence Agent, no further infrastructure is needed. documentation link
SUSE Linux supports both Azure API Fence Agent as well as SBD (Storage Based Death) fencing. For SBD fencing own VM(s)  - 1 or 3 (better) - should deployed to act as iSCSI block device providers. documentation link.
Advantage of SBD fencing is faster switch over time, which needs to be tested during deployment.

VMs located behind a standard load balancer loose default outbound connectivity and steps are needed to provide these. See documentation link, this applies to all nodes in a cluster. Load balancer provides the floating IP for virtual SAP hostname of the service uses - (A)SCS, ERS, DB name, DB passive/secondary, NFS, etc.

Title: Backup for SQL Server
Description:
Backups are the last line of defence to protect a customer’s sensitive data and critical business application components. There are several ways to back up an SAP SQL Server database, using database tools, Azure native tools or third-party backup products.
  1. SQL Server: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_sqlserver#backuprecovery-considerations-for-sql-server
    • SQL Server backups onto direct-attached Azure disks.
    • From SQL 2012 CU4, directly to an Azure Storage URL (blob).
    • Automated backup provided by the SQL Server IaaS Agent Extension.
    • Azure Backup for SQL Server VMs
Other ISVs solutions can be used as well (Commvault, Veritas, Veeam,...).

Title: Backup for HANA
Description:
Backups are the last line of defence to protect a customer’s sensitive data and critical business application components. There are several ways to back up an SAP HANA database in Azure, using database tools, Azure native tools or third-party backup products. Link to the official documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/sap-hana-backup-guide
Options available for backing up SAP HANA databases:
  1. Backup database to a file system: via SAP HANA Studio or HANA SQL statements directly to managed disks, Azure blob storage (blobxfer) or Azure file share.
  2. Azure Backup for HANA: Certified SAP solution which uses backint interface and doesn´t need infrastructure deployments (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/backup/sap-hana-db-about)
  3. HANA Backup using filesystem snapshots: Snapshots could be used as well with Azure Backup for HANA creating pre and post scripts. 
  4. Azure Netapp Files Snapshots: In case HANA database files is hosted in ANF, you can take snapshots directly from the ANF volumes with the azacsnap tool (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-netapp-files/azacsnap-introduction)
  5. Third-party tools: There are in the market solutions from ISVs like Commvault, Veeam, etc... that use the backing interface as well. (Ex. for Commvault: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/resources/protecting-sap-hana-in-azure/).

Description:
HANA Large instances are bare metal hardware offering together with storage, exclusively for SAP HANA.

SAP HANA certification in SAP hardware certification directory.
List of available SKUs and regions - docs link.

Differences to Azure virtual machines and the operations model - docs link.

Description:
Cloud monitoring guide - Monitoring strategy for cloud deployment models.

Title: SAP monitoring options in Azure
Description:
Mandatory for SAP support in Azure is to install Azure Monitoring Extention for SAP - as per note 2015553 - install AEM extension - documentation link.

Azure Monitor for SAP service to monitor SAP HANA, Pacemaker, SQL Server, SAP HANA replication,  Netweaver process monitor - documentation link.
Video introducing Azure Monitor for SAP.

SAP Solution Manager can still be used for SAP monitoring, will not contain Azure infrastructure details however beyond the operating system.

Title: Azure backup for VMs
Description:
Azure Backup for VM service to be used to protect Azure VMs and data on OS and data disks. 
Backup process explain in steps - docs link.
Details about limitations and support matrix - docs link.
Differences between crash consistent and application consistent - docs link. 

Disks can be excluded in VM backup, particularly for databases since they would not be consistent - docs link. In case of restore of full VM with such excluded disk, the excluded disks would need to be recreated - Azure disk resource as well as LVM/filesystem etc.

Title: Multi-SID on same cluster
Description:
As documented in last section of SAP note 1928533 - SAP Applications on Azure: Supported Products and Azure VM types , Microsoft supports documented High Availability architecture.
For some scenarios, this includes support of multiple SAP SIDs on same cluster. Typically up to 5 SAP SIDs in a cluster are supported however individual guides need to be confirmed about limitations and requirements.

Following documentation link leads to the section where Multi-SID SAP clusters are described.

Title: Windows clustering options
Description:
Windows Cluster is used for setting up High Availability of SAP on Azure. Windows Cluster can be used for :

  1. High Availability of Database 
  2. High Availability of SAP ASCS/ERS Layer

High Availability of MS SQL Database : 

Database high availability can be achieved by using DB Native replication between 2 nodes of DB. Windows Clustering is used to automate the failover between 2 DB Nodes.

High Availability of SAP ASCS/ERS : 

As ASCS can be a single point of failure in SAP Environment, we need to use OS clustering for its high Availability. Following are the different approaches for SAP ASCS/ERS high availability in windows environment.

Method

Title: Oracle RDBMS clustering/high-availability options
Description:
High availability for Oracle in Azure is typically achieved by using DB synchronization through the use of Oracle Data Guard, either simple Data Guard, FastStartFailOver or FarSync. This way no Azure components like Load Balancer for floating IP etc is needed. Documentation link for details.

Oracle on SAP whitepaper also exists depicting use of Oracle Data Guard for SAP high availability with both ABAP and JAVA stacks.

Clustering for failover with Oracle is not supported by Azure natively, on both Linux and Windows, Thus a 3rd party cluster manager is needed to provide tooling, how-to and support. See task item for 3rd party clustering solutions.

Title: Internet inbound/outbound connectivity for SAP
Description:
Traffic to and from SAP systems should be restricted by the usage of NSG Azure network security groups overview | Microsoft Docs and outbound connectivity limited to on prem connectivity to allow users to connect. Internet connectivity should be managed by Azure services like Azure Firewall, third party networking appliances (inbound/outbound) or Application Gateway (inbound https). SAP HANA infrastructure configurations and operations on Azure - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs


Public service endpoints needed for AAD, Azure Backup, ARM for fencing - or their private endpoint variants, if exist Private Link Documentation - Quickstarts, How to guides, and API references | Microsoft Docs. 

The different methods on how to achieve this are described at Public endpoint connectivity for Azure VMs&Standard ILB in SAP HA scenarios - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

Azure backup for HANA requires connectivity to Azure Backup service, Azure Storage, and Azure Active Directory 

Tutorial - Back up SAP HANA databases in Azure VMs - Azure Backup | Microsoft Doc

Title: Latency Testing
Description:
The latency between the SAP application and database tier is very sensitive therefore it is important that testing is carried out to ensure optimal performance.  Testing can be carried out using SAP Note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/1100926/E.  

If the network latency is found to be outside SAP recommendations customer should consider the use of Azure Proximity Placement Groups for optimisation as detailed here. Azure proximity placement groups for SAP applications - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

Title: Azure Site Recovery
Description:
Site Recovery helps ensure business continuity by keeping business apps and workloads running during outages. Site Recovery replicates workloads running on physical and virtual machines (VMs) from a primary site to a secondary location. When an outage occurs at your primary site, you fail over to secondary location, and access apps from there. After the primary location is running again, you can fail back to it.

Important:
  • Azure Site Recover must be used only on the application layer
  • If the DR Strategy chosen is Regional, customer need to build the DR landzone in the chosen region
Documentation:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/site-recovery-sap

Title: SAP notes for SAP on Azure
Description:
When we talk specifically to deploy SAP systems on Azure, there are some important SAP notes that must be reviewed in advance to avoid any issue in the future. 

Certified hardware, SAP products supported, OS and DB combinations supported, networking and monitoring considerations,... all these topics are recopiled in the SAP notes mentioned  in the following link: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/deployment-guide#resources

Title: SSO with SAP Solutions
Description:
Azure Active Directory integration which allows for single-sign-on into different SAP solutions are documented here
Get started with SAP on Azure VMs - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs ->Integrate Azure AD with SAP Applications
It includes a growing number of documentation about SSO for different SAP software solutions and services.

Title: SAP HANA scale-out options
Description:
One method for achieving HANA high availability is by configuring host auto failover. To configure host auto failover, you add one or more virtual machines to the HANA system and configure them as standby nodes. When active node fails, a standby node automatically takes over. In the presented configuration with Azure virtual machines, you achieve auto failover by using NFS on Azure NetApp Files.

  • Deploy a SAP HANA scale-out system with standby node on Azure VMs by using Azure NetApp Files on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
  • Deploy a SAP HANA scale-out system with standby node on Azure VMs by using Azure NetApp Files on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 

Another method to achieve HANA high availability for HANA scale-out installations, is to configure HANA system replication and protect the solution with Pacemaker cluster to allow automatic failover. When an active node fails, the cluster fails over the HANA resources to the other site.

·    High availability of SAP HANA scale-out system on Red Hat Enterprise Linux

  • Verify and troubleshoot SAP HANA scale-out high-availability setup on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
 SAP HANA scale-out can be achieved also through use of premiumSSD without a standby node - Configuring Azure infrastructure for SAP HANA scale-out

Title: Disaster Recovery for SAP components in Azure
Description:
For Azure disaster recovery depends on utilizing another, at least several hundred km away Azure region - documentation link.

BCDR for SAP should address following design:
  • Secondary Azure region to be enabled for SAP workload - networking, DNS, User-Access (AD), surround enablement systems such as print server/3rd party interfaces.
  • For Azure Backup, VMs as well as databases, cross region restore need to be prepared and configured - documentation link.
  • Disaster recovery plan created and tested regularly.
Architecture accounting for SAP BCDR depicted and described - documentation link.

Only in special circumstances, if unable by company policy or regulations, to utilize another Azure region for BCDR a combined HA/DR configuration could be used.

Title: Availability Set/Availability Zone for SAP architecture
Description:
Main documentation link -  SAP workload configurations with Azure Availability Zones

For SAP application layers - ASCS/SCS, application server tier, database layer - when running in highly-available setup of more than 1 VM per each layer, you can utilize Azure availability sets (AvSet) or availability zone (AvZone) deployment. Both AvSet or AvZone need to be specified during VM deployment and can be changed only by VM re-deployment.

Availability set is a logical grouping of VMs, deployed in one datacenter and higher SLA than single VMs otherwise would  have. Currently VMs in AvSet are deployed inside the same location. Use the maximum failure domain and update domain when creating an AvSet for SAP. 

Availability zones distribute VMs in different zones within one Azure region, to protect from datacenter level failure.

AvSets are currently deployed together in one location, spread accounting for failure/update downtime.
AvZone deployment for SAP needs to address latency between these zones and based on the region and latency, account for active/active or active/passive deployment model.

Title: Third party data ingestion tools
Description:
To enable businesses to gain real-time insights from their SAP data, exists a new joint offer with Qlik (formerly Attunity) that brings Azure Synapse, Power BI, and Qlik Data Integration together for end-to-end supply chain intelligence, finance analytics, and more. Details in the following links:
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/save-up-to-76-percent-on-azure-synapse-analytics-and-gain-breathtaking-insights-of-your-erp-data/.
https://go.qlik.com/Qlik-Unleash-Your-SAP-Data.html.

In addtion, there are several companies in the market (ISVs) that developed specific solutions using Azure services for extracting SAP data directly through different SAP layers (app, database) or reading database logs, and consolidating these data with other non SAP data for analytics purposes.

Description:

https://azuremarketplace.microsoft.com/en-us/marketplace/apps?search=sap%20migration&page=1

Description:
Backups are the last line of defence to protect a customer’s sensitive data and critical business application components. There are several ways to back up an SAP Oracle database, using database tools, Azure native tools or third-party backup products.

Other ISVs solutions can be used as well (Commvault, Veritas, Veeam,...).

Title: Backup for SAP ASE
Description:
Backups are the last line of defence to protect a customer’s sensitive data and critical business application components. For backing up an SAP ASE database, the recommended way is using database tools or third-party backup products.

  1. SAP ASE: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_sapase (Backup provided over multiple disks in order to improve the IOPS throughput on that striped volume).

Other ISVs solutions can be used as well (Commvault, Veritas, Veeam,...).

Title: SQL Server
Description:
Azure storage best practices for SQL Server for SAP follow the general recommendations mentioned in SQL Server Azure Virtual Machines DBMS deployment for SAP workload - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

General SQL Server storage recommendations can be found here Storage configuration for SQL Server VMs - SQL Server on Azure VM | Microsoft Docs

SQL Server storage performance recommendations can be found here Performance guidelines for SQL Server in Azure - SQL Server on Azure VM | Microsoft Docs

Title: Azure resource deployment options and automation
Description:
Automated deployments are the best way to achieve standardized and repeatable deployments with expected results. There are different options available:


ARM templates on Azure Virtual Machines deployment for SAP NetWeaver - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs


There are a limited number of SAP images available on Marketplace on Azure Portal Marketplace - Microsoft Azure, search for SAP (careful: some of them including managed services)


Build your own scripts on basis of PowerShell Overview of Azure PowerShell | Microsoft Docs or CLI 

https://docs.microsoft.com/cli/azure/


Microsoft SAP Deployment Automation Framework that provides Terraform templates and Ansible playbooks which can be used to build and configure the environments to run SAP on Azure. GitHub - Azure/sap-hana: Tools to create, monitor and maintain SAP landscapes in Azure

 

Another option to easily setup at SAP system on Azure for a short timeframe is to use https://cal.sap.com/ Access is limited timewise (trial installations), not intended for production usage and not really reflecting performance you can get out of a system based infrastructure deployed according Microsoft best practices.


SAP LaMa on Azure also allows cloning and copying of SAP systems SAP LaMa connector for Azure - Azure Virtual Machines | Microsoft Docs

Title: DB2 using managed disks
Description:
Direct link to the official documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_sapase#recommendations-on-vm-and-disk-structure-for-sap-ase-deployments

Depending on the OS used, the following caveats must bear in mind:
  1. Windows Server:
    1. No SMB support. Must be locally attached storage (NTFS).
    2. Use Storage Pool for Premium Disks
  2. SLES and RHEL options:
    1. Locally storage attached.
    2. Filesystem: xfs, ext3 and ext4 are supported. LVM or MDADM with premium disks.
For M series, enable write accelerator to the online redo log files, and for non M series, use UltraSSD.

Title: HANA using Azure Netapp Files - cost conscious
Description:
Main document: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/hana-vm-operations-netapp#sizing-for-hana-database-on-azure-netapp-files.

All the recommendations from a cost-conscious perspective are included in the following document: https://www.netapp.com/pdf.html?item=/media/17152-tr4746pdf.pdf. 

In summary, these are:
  1. Overprovisioning: Volumes might have to be overprovisioned for non-productive SAP HANA systems, depending on customer performance requirements. 
  2. Optimization for Shared Files Data: Creation of only one volume for all shared files of a single system and create a folder structure within that volume.
  3. Optimization for Multiple SIDs: Combining data or log volumes from multiple independent SIDs into a single volume. 
  4. Use of snapshots (Public Preview): Azure Application Consistent Snapshot tool (AzAcSnap) is a command-line tool that enables the use of snapshots instead of backup tools.
  5. Use of CRR (Public Preview): CRR could be used to replicate volumes between different tiers (Ultra to Standard) in a DR scenario.

Title: SAP Principal Propagation with Azure AD
Description:
There are multiple angles to SingleSignOn to SAP. Below sources focus on web-based communication and integration with SAP Business Technology Platform. However, the approach can be adapted to use the Microsoft on-premise data gateway alternatively.

For SAP GUI you either need to rely on SAP GUI for HTML to be able to use Azure AD or consider Azure AD Domain Services/ Active Directory Domain Services (self-managed domain) so you can setup Kerberos. With local AD there is a synching mechanism to Azure AD but SAML based sign-in is not supported with SAP GUI Desktop.
  • Detailed YouTube session on Teams Chatbot with SAP including principal propagation
  • Entry into blog series on SAP Principal Propagation with Azure AD

Title: HANA using managed disks
Description:
Direct link to full documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/hana-vm-operations-storage

Azure VM running SAP HANA need to meet SAP's requirements of 400MB/s throughput for /hana/data filesystem and 250MB/s throughput as well as sub 1ms write I/O for /hana/log filesystem, both peak KPIs for different I/O block sizes.

In order to meet this requirement in cost-efficient manner, the following is required:
  • Own Azure managed disks for /hana/data, /hana/log, /hana/shared, /usr/sap and, if needed /hana/backup filesystems
  • Using LVM striping or Linux software raid0 through mdadm to spread I/O over multiple disks for /hana/data and /hana/log
  • Correct Azure VM caching for all data disks, with write accelerator enabled for disks containing /hana/log
  • Recommended to use strong naming for managed disks - <vm-name>-datadisk<lun#>-<purpose> - sapt01db1-datadisk0-hanadata
List of recommended storage design is contained in this documentation.
Correct caching settings for managed disks and striping information is contained in this documentation section.
Linux I/O scheduler settings are contained in same documentation, direct link to section.

As an alternative to using LVM/mdadm striping across many disks, one can use SAP HANA data volume partitioning. One benefit of this approach is no need for LVM initial setup and allowing extending storage for a growing SAP HANA system. Direct link to section.

Title: Azure subscription and access management
Description:
Decide on a model for Azure landing zone and subscription design. Documentation link
Use implementation options available for chosen landing zone and thus Azure subscription(s)

Ensure sufficient vCPU quota for a subscription is requested early.

As for most resources names cannot be changed, ensure strong naming standards are agreed on early in project. Link 2 and example Excel for Azure naming.

Manage access to your Azure environment through Azure role-based access control (RBAC)

Title: Understand challenges with SAP data extraction to Azure
Description:
Before jumping into connectors we recommend checking the pre-requisites for the data load:
  • SAP GRC investment: Many customers have a sophisticated, audit relevent setup that ensures data can only be seen/edited by authorized employees. When you extract data from SAP with context-less adapters like table connector, ODBC or OpenHub that mechanism is lost. You need to remodel or ensure that data is only extracted in a form that all people further downstream are allowed to consume. Usually this is done through aggregation.
  • Time slices: Some objects within SAP are subject to time dependent changes, so called time slicing (e.g. renaming of master data). You need to be aware that this impacts your data loads because you create redundancy or even misleading data entries. A typical approach would be excluding historic queries to avoid the conflict
  • SAP Data archiving: To reduce storage but retain data for audit purposes for instance, there is a built-in archiving mechanism on the SAP system. Be aware that your data queries won't reflect data since it has no access to archived data outside of SAP.
  • Delta-Extraction (aka Change Data Capture): Raw extractions like with the table connector have no built-in mechanism to identify deltas. You need to take care of that in your implementation yourself.
  • Data loading times from ECC/S4 into BW: Many loads into BW are only done on a batch basis overnight. In case you need a higher frequency you might consider "hooking" into the source system directly.

Title: Oracle using managed disks
Description:
Direct link to the official documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/dbms_guide_oracle

Depending on the OS used, the following caveats must bear in mind:
  1. Windows Server:
    1. No SMB support. Locally attached storage.
    2. Use Storage Pool for Premium Disks
  2. Oracle Linux options:
    1. Oracle ASM highly recommended
    2. Without ASM - filesystem: xfs and ext4 are supported. LVM or MDADM with premium disks.
For M series, enable write accelerator to the online redo log files, and for non M series, consider using UltraSSD.
Detailed information about filesystems supported for the different OS and Oracle versions are in SAP note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/2039619.

Key metrics to use for sizing storage requirements using Oracle AWR reports.
